title: 104_s760
content: The "Medicare Commission Act of 1995" is established. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program is established with 15 members appointed by the President, Majority Leader of the Senate, and Speaker of the House. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program consists of 15 members appointed by various officials. Five members are appointed by the Speaker of the House of Representatives, with restrictions on political party affiliation. Appointments must be made by November 30, 1995, and members serve for the life of the Commission. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed and will meet at the Chairman's call. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program consists of 15 members appointed by various officials. The Commission shall hold its first meeting at the call of the Chairman. A majority of members constitute a quorum, and a lesser number can hold hearings. The Chairman is selected from among the members. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with reviewing analyses of the current and long-term financial condition of the Medicare trust funds, identifying potential threats to their solvency, analyzing solutions to ensure financial integrity and health benefits, and providing recommendations to the Secretary of Health and Human Services, the President, and Congress. The Medicare trust funds include the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund. The Commission's report is due by December 31, 1996. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and use postal services. They may take testimony and evidence as needed. Additionally, the Commission can request information directly from federal departments or agencies. Commission personnel matters are also addressed. Members of the Commission, whether federal government officers or private citizens, serve without additional compensation. Non-government members may receive travel expenses. The Chairman of the Commission may appoint an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can provide administrative and support services. Members of the Commission serve without extra pay, and non-government members may receive travel expenses. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and staff without following civil service laws. The executive director's compensation is determined by the Chairman and cannot exceed a certain level. Federal government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. Temporary and intermittent services can be procured as needed. The Chairman of the Commission can procure temporary and intermittent services at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting its report. Funding for the Commission's expenses will come from available funds for the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
